He was frustrated.  
“Not until you let me kiss your hands! That’s it! I’m getting up, and we’re moving on! I’m a total mess, unworthy of you, and honestly, I’m ashamed. I’m not good enough to love you, but every decent guy should show respect, and I’ve done that. Here are your lodgings, and Rodya was right to kick your Pyotr Petrovitch to the curb. How could he put you in a place like this? It’s ridiculous! Do you know who stays here? And you’re his fiancée? Seriously? Well, I’ll be real with you: your fiancé is a jerk.”  

“Excuse me, Mr. Razumihin, you’re forgetting…” Pulcheria Alexandrovna started.  
“Yes, yes, you’re right. I lost my cool, and I’m sorry,” Razumihin quickly apologized. “But you can’t be mad at me for saying this! I’m being honest, not because… um, well, that would be embarrassing. Not because I’m in… um! Anyway, I won’t say why. I just can’t. But we all saw today when he came in that guy is not one of us. It’s not just because he got his hair done or was eager to show off. He’s a spy, a schemer, a cheap skate, and a clown. That’s clear. Do you think he’s smart? No way, he’s a fool. And is he good enough for you? Good heavens! Look, ladies,” he paused on the way upstairs to their rooms, “even though my friends are all drunk, they’re honest. We might talk a lot of nonsense, and I do too, but we’ll figure it out.”

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Razumihin expresses his disdain for Pulcheria's fiancé, calling him a scoundrel and emphasizing the importance of honesty among friends.
